# No More Lunch With The Cool Kids: Biglaw Firm Bans Client From Its Cafeteria
## Amid legal dispute, firm takes away longtime client's lunch privileges.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 12, 2019 at 1:43 PMSeptember 13, 2019 at 9:33 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/no-more-lunch-with-the-cool-kids-biglaw-firm-bans-client-from-its-cafeteria/&text=No%20More%20Lunch%20With%20The%20Cool%20Kids:%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Bans%20Client%20From%20Its%20Cafeteria)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/no-more-lunch-with-the-cool-kids-biglaw-firm-bans-client-from-its-cafeteria/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/09/no-more-lunch-with-the-cool-kids-biglaw-firm-bans-client-from-its-cafeteria/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Investment bank Perella Weinberg has long enjoyed a unique perk for a Biglaw client — access to the firm cafeteria. The arrangement, born out of Parella sharing a GM Building office with Weil, allowed bankers to feast upon the offerings in Weil’s 26th floor lunch spot. But now those privileges [have been revoked](https://nypost.com/2019/09/12/law-firm-weil-gotshal-bans-longtime-client-from-its-cafeteria/) amid a legal dispute between Parella and Weil over [allegations that Weil botched pay packages costing former Parella bankers millions](https://nypost.com/2019/08/22/top-firm-weil-gotshal-manges-faces-irs-crackdown-over-pay-packages/).

You know what they say, “We’ll Get You And Mangle Your Comp Package.”

The whole affair involves pay that wasn’t properly deferred to two Parella bankers who were later fired. They had sued for deferred compensation and Weil allegedly discovered four years after the fact that the deferral hadn’t been handled properly. Now the bank is understandably testy:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Last month, Peter Weinberg, one of the investment bank’s founders, and partner Robert Steele told Weil that it could be fired, according to a person briefed on the conversation.

The “not-so-veiled threat” came after The Post revealed that partners at Weil had botched the pay packages for two former Perella bankers, and had kept the bank in the dark about the mistake for years.

The error could lead to millions of dollars in back taxes, penalties and interest — and finger-pointing about who is responsible for covering the bill.

That’s why the firm pulled the plug on the cafeteria deal. But according to the Post, some people were already questioning the arrangement:

“It’s weird for a law firm to let people be in private spaces unaccompanied, because you have private and confidential concerns,” one former Weil lawyer told The Post. “Especially investment bankers, who know of deals people are on and are competing with.”

I’ve not been to Weil’s cafeteria, so I can’t speak with specificity, but if it’s anything like the Biglaw cafeterias I have seen, the 26th floor is almost certainly a public-facing floor and not one where work gets done. Still, gossiping attorneys could divulge information while waiting in line for a burger, but how many associates are really making small talk during their authorized five-minute trip down to get some food to nervously consume at their desks?

In fact, it’s not entirely uncommon for clients or opposing counsel to be escorted into the cafeteria so Weil employees should know better than to be spilling the beans on major confidential information anyway. If that’s not a lesson the firm drilled into its people from the beginning, they should do so now, regardless of whether or not Parella gets to hang out there.

Now we’ll have investment bankers who will just have to wait in line at the Cafe Metro like proles. Welcome to Elizabeth Warren’s America!

# Morning Docket: 11.20.18
## * ACLU and Center for Constitutional Rights score win with court order proclaiming the obvious: No, you can't blanket deny asylum seekers. [[Associated Press via Huffington Post](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-asylum-ban-legal-challenge_us_5bf3b32ee4b0d9e7283c8e99)] * Cyrus Vance accuses someone of seeking publicity over justice. [[Variety](https://variety.com/2018/biz/news/manhattan-da-weinstein-lawyer-public-circus-1203032399/)] * Are you suggesting that law firms and clients don't listen to each other? [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/11/19/amid-innovation-buzz-surveys-point-to-law-firm-client-mismatch/)] * The Trump administration wanted to share census answers with the cops... which is why they were so hot to get those illegal citizenship questions on there. It's like 3D checkers of bumbling xenophobia over here. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/social-issues/trump-administration-officials-suggested-sharing-census-responses-with-law-enforcement-court-documents-show/2018/11/19/41679018-ec46-11e8-8679-934a2b33be52_story.html)] * The SEC's whistleblower program handed out more awards this year than ever before! Unsurprisingly, the article makes no mention of Justice following up on any of these financial crimes. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1103370/sec-s-whistleblower-program-hits-its-stride-in-2018)] * Third Circuit taking a stab at New Jersey's ban on high-capacity magazines -- just as the Framers' envisioned. [[New Jersey Law Journal](https://www.law.com/2018/10/01/judge-wont-halt-states-limits-on-large-capacity-gun-magazines/)] * What are law schools training students for? Debt management, maybe?[[Forbes](https://www.forbes.com/sites/markcohen1/2018/11/19/what-are-law-schools-training-students-for/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onNovember 20, 2018 at 8:19 AM

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 05.26.16
## * David Mourey, the former assistant dean for bar preparation and academic success at Barry Law, was fired after students continued to fail the bar exam, but in a recently filed gender discrimination and retaliation lawsuit, he claims he was discriminated against because he was "singled out for discipline by an all-female management team." We may have more on this later. [[Orlando Sentinel](http://www.orlandosentinel.com/features/education/os-barry-lawsuit-gender-discrimination-story.html)] * Despite the [wishes of the public and rumors of his firing](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/irony-alert-ken-starr-should-lose-his-job-for-not-investigating-real-sex-crimes/) in the face of the Baylor University coverup of reports of rape and sexual assault by football players, "Ken Starr is [still] president and chancellor of Baylor University." According to a university spokeswoman, the school has not yet finished reviewing Pepper Hamilton's report on the matter, but Baylor will likely make an announcement by June 3. [[Associated Press](http://www.phillyvoice.com/baylor-says-ken-starr-is-president-amid-speculatio/)] * "We are willing to fight this all the way to the Supreme Court if we have to." Eleven states have filed suit against the Obama Administration in an effort to get around its guidance on transgender rights for children in schools, calling the policy a "massive social experiment." The states suing are Alabama, Arizona, Georgia, Louisiana, Maine, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, West Virginia, and Wisconsin. [[Reuters](http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-lgbt-idUSKCN0YG2NT)] * Sumner Redstone turns 93 years old tomorrow, and he's been in and out of court for the past few months in a battle to prove he's mentally competent. The salacious case filed by his former female companion may have been dismissed, but now he's attempting to fend off claims from Viacom directors who were ousted from a trust that will control his media holdings if he dies or is found incompetent. [[DealBook / New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/26/business/media/a-complicated-legal-battle-over-sumner-redstones-mental-acuity.html)] * Now that the world knows that PayPal's co-founder provided funding for Hulk Hogan's invasion of privacy suit against Gawker, it's time to take a look at the lawyer who's been representing the wrestler. Charles Harder is no stranger to Hollywood cases, and may be a longtime fan of litigation finance since he "[tries] to win and do so in a way that's cost effective for a client, so they don't lose when they're winning." [[WSJ Law Blog](http://blogs.wsj.com/law/2016/05/25/lawyer-behind-gawker-lawsuit-has-close-ties-to-hollywood/?ref=/blogs/law)] * Since [revenge litigation finance's recent invention](http://dealbreaker.com/2016/05/peter-thiel-revenge-litigation-finance/), what's there to keep billionaires from destroying you with lawsuits? Unfortunately, the answer to this question is not much, especially when "there is no obligation to disclose the litigation financing arrangements" that have been made. Ethical issues aside, we really hope the super-rich wield their new power to ruin lives through rented lawsuits carefully. [[Fortune](http://fortune.com/2016/05/25/thiel-gawker/)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 26, 2016 at 8:59 AMMay 26, 2016 at 2:55 PM

* “We are willing to fight this all the way to the Supreme Court if we have to.” Eleven states have filed suit against the Obama Administration in an effort to get around its guidance on transgender rights for children in schools, calling the policy a “massive social experiment.” The states suing are Alabama, Arizona, Georgia, Louisiana, Maine, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, West Virginia, and Wisconsin. [[Reuters](http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-lgbt-idUSKCN0YG2NT)]

* Sumner Redstone turns 93 years old tomorrow, and he’s been in and out of court for the past few months in a battle to prove he’s mentally competent. The salacious case filed by his former female companion may have been dismissed, but now he’s attempting to fend off claims from Viacom directors who were ousted from a trust that will control his media holdings if he dies or is found incompetent. [[DealBook / New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/26/business/media/a-complicated-legal-battle-over-sumner-redstones-mental-acuity.html)]

* Now that the world knows that PayPal’s co-founder provided funding for Hulk Hogan’s invasion of privacy suit against Gawker, it’s time to take a look at the lawyer who’s been representing the wrestler. Charles Harder is no stranger to Hollywood cases, and may be a longtime fan of litigation finance since he “[tries] to win and do so in a way that’s cost effective for a client, so they don’t lose when they’re winning.” [[WSJ Law Blog](http://blogs.wsj.com/law/2016/05/25/lawyer-behind-gawker-lawsuit-has-close-ties-to-hollywood/?ref=/blogs/law)]

* Since [revenge litigation finance’s recent invention](http://dealbreaker.com/2016/05/peter-thiel-revenge-litigation-finance/), what’s there to keep billionaires from destroying you with lawsuits? Unfortunately, the answer to this question is not much, especially when “there is no obligation to disclose the litigation financing arrangements” that have been made. Ethical issues aside, we really hope the super-rich wield their new power to ruin lives through rented lawsuits carefully. [[Fortune](http://fortune.com/2016/05/25/thiel-gawker/)]

# Even Biglaw Associates Struggle To Pay Their Massive Student Loans
## High salaries or not, student loans are still weighing lawyers down.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 16, 2021 at 3:15 PMAugust 16, 2021 at 1:52 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/even-biglaw-associates-struggle-to-pay-their-massive-student-loans/&text=Even%20Biglaw%20Associates%20Struggle%20To%20Pay%20Their%20Massive%20Student%20Loans)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/even-biglaw-associates-struggle-to-pay-their-massive-student-loans/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/even-biglaw-associates-struggle-to-pay-their-massive-student-loans/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s a seemingly absurd position: You can make enough money to be in a very high-income tax bracket, but home ownership is completely out of reach. I’m saying that as someone who feels very lucky.

— [Marcella Jayne](https://www.foley.com/en/people/j/jayne-marcella-m), a third-year litigation associate at Foley & Lardner who now makes more than $215,000, commenting on [sizeable student loan indebtedness](https://www.reuters.com/legal/government/debt-transformed-my-life-lawyers-weigh-student-loan-reprieve-2021-08-10/) following college and law school. Jayne, a single mother to two children, had been paying $2,200 per month on her $180,000 balance prior to the federal student loan payment moratorium. “We were headed toward the cliff,” she said of affording special needs childcare services coupled with her monthly loan payment, which was higher than her monthly Manhattan rent. While Jayne is thankful for the reprieve, she says she’s looking for something more. “I feel like it’s a band aid. I want policy changes.”

# Harvard Law School Students Organize #DumpKirkland Campaign Over Biglaw Employment Arbitration Agreements
## The battle over Biglaw arbitration employment contracts continues...
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 13, 2018 at 12:15 PMNovember 14, 2018 at 9:13 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/harvard-law-school-students-organize-dumpkirkland-campaign-over-biglaw-employment-arbitration-agreements/&text=Harvard%20Law%20School%20Students%20Organize%20#DumpKirkland%20Campaign%20Over%20Biglaw%20Employment%20Arbitration%20Agreements)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/harvard-law-school-students-organize-dumpkirkland-campaign-over-biglaw-employment-arbitration-agreements/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/harvard-law-school-students-organize-dumpkirkland-campaign-over-biglaw-employment-arbitration-agreements/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Time’s up, Biglaw.

Earlier this year outrage over mandatory arbitration agreements in Biglaw employment contracts hit a fevered pitch. It all started when [Ian Samuel](http://hls.harvard.edu/faculty/directory/11599/Samuel/) leaked [on Twitter](https://twitter.com/isamuel/status/977699755605274629) the [content of](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/biglaw-firm-tries-to-force-summer-associates-to-arbitrate-sexual-harassment-claims/) Munger Tolles & Olson’s agreement that they’d asked summer associates to sign. In the face of backlash, the firm responded by backtracking on the mandatory arbitration clause for all employees. Other firms like [Orrick](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/this-biglaw-firm-is-the-first-to-step-forward-and-do-away-with-mandatory-arbitration-for-all-employees/?rf=1) and [Skadden](http://www.law.com/therecorder/2018/03/26/after-munger-metoo-snafu-orrick-touts-end-of-arbitration-agreements/) followed suit, changing their employment contracts with the changing times.

But the position of a handful of firms is hardly enough to hold the legal industry accountable. So a survey was sent on behalf of T14 law schools to every law firm recruiting on their campuses, asking that the firms disclose whether they require summer associates to sign mandatory arbitration agreements and nondisclosure agreements related to workplace misconduct, including but not limited to sexual harassment. The [results of the survey](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/which-biglaw-firms-still-require-summer-associates-to-sign-mandatory-arbitration-agreements/?rf=1) provided essential information to law students and lateral candidates alike about the Biglaw firms, but not everyone chose to disclose the state of their mandatory arbitration agreements.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
This lack of transparency is disappointing, particularly when the[ largest law firm by gross revenue](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/theres-a-new-biggest-law-firm-by-gross-revenue-in-town/) opts out of the disclosures. But this hasn’t stopped a group of Harvard Law student activists, organized as the [Pipeline Parity Project.](http://www.pipelineparityproject.org/about/) They’ve been able to dig up the Kirkland & Ellis [Employment Arbitration Contract, ](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1yaqiB8btErQno4qSQ8FCdfstGK04Qvd6sjBEzxzSQdQ/edit?usp=sharing)and as [Vail Kohnert-Yount](http://www.pipelineparityproject.org/author/avk/)[,](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1yaqiB8btErQno4qSQ8FCdfstGK04Qvd6sjBEzxzSQdQ/edit?usp=sharing) a Harvard 2L and member of the Project, notes:

Kirkland might be trying to keep its love affair with forced arbitration a secret, but we have the receipts.

So now that they’ve revealed what’s really behind the closed door of Kirkland’s employment contract they’re asking law students to #DumpKirkland until they do away with forced arbitration agreements for all employees:

[I] f Kirkland won’t stop its forced arbitration racket—and indeed, won’t even own up to it—it’s up to us to educate ourselves and our peers and take action.

That’s why we’re asking all the law students who are headed into recruitment season this year: Don’t interview with Kirkland & Ellis until they promise to stop making any of their employees—no associate, paralegal, custodian, or contractor—sign these coercive contracts.

This is our way of saying to Kirkland & Ellis and all other employers, dump your forced arbitration agreements, or we’ll #DumpKirkland and dump you too.

# Staff, Summer Program On Chopping Block At This Am Law 200 Firm
## Another firm feels the COVID-19 pinch.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 1, 2020 at 2:45 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/staff-summer-program-on-chopping-block-at-this-am-law-200-firm/&text=Staff,%20Summer%20Program%20On%20Chopping%20Block%20At%20This%20Am%20Law%20200%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/staff-summer-program-on-chopping-block-at-this-am-law-200-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/staff-summer-program-on-chopping-block-at-this-am-law-200-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Dickinson Wright, a firm that took the [128th spot](https://www.law.com/law-firm-profile/?id=85&name=Dickinson-Wright) on the 2019 Am Law 200, is yet another Biglaw firm that is planning for the financial fallout from COVID-19. Like so many other of its peers, the firm has decided to institute austerity measures to minimize the harm of decreased revenues.

So what is going on at the firm? Tipsters report staff layoffs. The firm has also pulled the plug on its summer associate program (though everyone who was scheduled to participate will receive an offer). And the new batch of associates scheduled to start in the fall? Postponed until January 2021.

According to [reports](https://www.law.com/2020/04/30/pay-cuts-layoffs-and-more-how-law-firms-are-managing-the-pandemic/), the firm has issued the following statement about its austerity measures:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
“Our leadership has developed a tiered contingency plan for the potential of reduced revenues. This plan entails reducing discretionary spending, implementing an approximately 3% reduction in workforce, canceling our summer program yet providing everyone in that summer class an offer, and deferring our fall incoming class of associates to January.”

If your firm or organization is slashing salaries, closing its doors, or reducing the ranks of its lawyers or staff, whether through open layoffs, stealth layoffs, or voluntary buyouts, please don’t hesitate to let us know. Our vast network of tipsters is part of what makes Above the Law thrive. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Layoffs/Salary%20Cuts) or text us (646-820-8477).

If you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Layoff Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the layoff alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each layoff, salary cut, or furlough announcement that we publish.

# Marc Kasowitz Writes Angry Emails And Everyone Completely Overreacts
## Kasowitz didn't owe anyone any apologies for his email.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJuly 14, 2017 at 12:57 PMJuly 14, 2017 at 3:30 PM
16
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/marc-kasowitz-writes-angry-emails-and-everyone-completely-overreacts/&text=Marc%20Kasowitz%20Writes%20Angry%20Emails%20And%20Everyone%20Completely%20Overreacts)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/marc-kasowitz-writes-angry-emails-and-everyone-completely-overreacts/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/marc-kasowitz-writes-angry-emails-and-everyone-completely-overreacts/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Marc Kasowitz (screenshot via YouTube)

When a random stranger emailed Marc Kasowitz with the subject line,“Resign Now,” apparently Kasowitz knew that he had the tools and talent to discover exactly who his critic was! Even though it’s easier than ever before to anonymize oneself on the internet, Kasowitz must have had every confidence in his ability to backward-navigate all the potentially obscuring cover and make a positive identification. Then, just to show this stranger that the Kas is a master of email, he sent [a good natured reply](https://www.propublica.org/article/marc-kasowitz-trump-lawyer-threat-emails-maddow):



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Oh. Well then.

It’s unclear what the most interesting wrinkle is here. It could be that before this email he sent the simple message “F*ck you,” complete with asterisk, which… why? But I think the “Watch your back , bitch,” with the unnecessary added space you’d expect from the [Predisent’s attorney](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/marc-kasowitz-takes-break-from-partying-at-trump-hotel-to-talk-to-the-press/), is the real winner here.

When this story broke yesterday afternoon, we received this statement from a spokesperson:

Mr. Kasowitz, who is tied up with client matters, said he intends to apologize to the writer of the email referenced in today’s ProPublica story.  While no excuse, the email came at the end of a very long day that at 10 pm was not yet over.   “The person sending that email is entitled to his opinion and I should not have responded in that inappropriate manner,” Mr. Kasowitz said.  “I intend to send him an email stating just that.  This is one of those times where one wishes he could reverse the clock, but of course I can’t.”

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
An apology? Really? I get that this is kind of pro forma in these situations, but Kasowitz didn’t owe this person anything. Oh, he was mean to someone? I can’t believe a major law firm attorney was — gasp! — mean to someone. You’re writing the lawyer for the president, put on some big kid pants! Did the guy expect Kas to respond, “Golly, I didn’t think of it that way before”?

There was some buzz about whether or not the email exchange constituted harassment, which is dumb. If Kasowitz emailed someone unsolicited and told them to “watch their back,” then that would come across as threatening, but as a response to someone calling him out — who cares? Look, we’ve had some fairly tough criticism of Kasowitz in these pages, but if we slid into his inbox and told him to resign he’d be well within his rights to hurl some invective.

Someone yapped at Kasowitz, and Kasowitz swung back. It probably wasn’t the most prudent thing to say in an email exchange because — [as the Trump administration is starting to realize](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/do-you-have-what-it-takes-to-be-a-great-defense-attorney/) — those are permanent records of one’s mistakes, but everyone needs to chill out and let a guy be human here. The only person who should care about this is Trump, who would have a legitimate complaint that his lawyer caused so much unnecessary negative attention, but Trump’s whole political strategy seems to be “create as much unnecessary negative attention as possible to numb the audience,” so he probably doesn’t even care. This Roy Cohn impersonation might even salve the reportedly [strained client relationship](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/07/marc-kasowitz-is-waking-up-to-a-bad-morning/).

That said, Kasowitz [probably should resign](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/when-people-start-writing-about-you-destroying-your-firm-things-arent-going-well/) from this nightmare of a representation. I don’t mind being told to f*ck off on that one.

[Trump Lawyer Marc Kasowitz Threatens Stranger in Emails: ‘Watch Your Back, Bitch’](https://www.propublica.org/article/marc-kasowitz-trump-lawyer-threat-emails-maddow) [ProPublica]

# The Reason Why Layoffs Are A Must For Some Law Firms
## Layoffs can be a difficult choice, but they may need to happen for firms to move ahead successfully.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 18, 2023 at 5:29 PMDecember 18, 2023 at 3:10 PM
18
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/the-reason-why-layoffs-are-a-must-for-some-law-firms/&text=The%20Reason%20Why%20Layoffs%20Are%20A%20Must%20For%20Some%20Law%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/the-reason-why-layoffs-are-a-must-for-some-law-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/the-reason-why-layoffs-are-a-must-for-some-law-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

Discipline is the name of the game in most firms that outperform their peers. That means discipline in revenue generation and expense management. Given that the largest single expense for law firms is compensation, it makes sense to regularly manage capacity, and therefore control expenses, as a matter of course as demand and other drivers fluctuate.

— Kent Zimmermann, a consultant for law firm strategy and management at Zeughauser Group, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/12/18/proskauer-layoffs-underscore-string-of-big-law-cuts-in-2023/) on the reason why some law firms must conduct layoffs from time to time in order to maintain their status quo.

# First Major Biglaw Firm Matches The 2020 Cravath Bonus Scale
## It's bonus time at this leading law firm!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 23, 2020 at 5:39 PMNovember 24, 2020 at 9:08 AM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/paul-weiss-bonuses-2020/&text=First%20Major%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Matches%20The%202020%20Cravath%20Bonus%20Scale)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/paul-weiss-bonuses-2020/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/paul-weiss-bonuses-2020/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Less than an hour after [Cravath](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/cravath-bonuses/) officially kicked off the 2020 bonus season by matching [Baker McKenzie’s](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/breaking-biglaw-bonus-season-comes-early-and-no-its-not-cravath/) year-end bonus scale and sweetening the pot by matching the [Davis Polk](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/wow-davis-polk-raises-the-bar-on-bonuses/) special bonus scale, another elite law firm has jumped to match the market rate as quickly as possible.

Which firm is the first to match the official 2020 Biglaw bonus scale?

Paul Weiss is first firm to hop on the Cravath bonus bandwagon. Bonuses at the firm will be paid to associates on December 18.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
It’s worth mentioning that almost two months ago, Paul Weiss [refused](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/paul-weiss-wont-be-offering-fall-bonuses-and-associates-are-angry/) to match the Davis Polk fall bonuses because it “would not be appropriate,” seeing as the firm’s clients and others were “experiencing unprecedented economic trauma” because of the pandemic. And yet… here’s the firm, matching those very bonuses now, when coronavirus cases are worsening, all because Cravath did it first.

UPDATE: Yes, we know that in early October, Paul Weiss “pledge[d] to retain [its] position as a market leader in compensation, taking into account any special bonuses paid by [its] peer firms.” We wrote about that [here](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/paul-weiss-wont-be-offering-fall-bonuses-and-associates-are-angry/).

# Anatomy Of A Deal: The Backstory Behind Scott Barshay's Move From Cravath To Paul Weiss
## How much might the responsible recruiter have earned for making this placement?
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onApril 6, 2016 at 5:35 PMApril 7, 2016 at 5:53 PM
7
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/anatomy-of-a-deal-the-backstory-behind-scott-barshays-move-from-cravath-to-paul-weiss/&text=Anatomy%20Of%20A%20Deal:%20The%20Backstory%20Behind%20Scott%20Barshay’s%20Move%20From%20Cravath%20To%20Paul%20Weiss)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/anatomy-of-a-deal-the-backstory-behind-scott-barshays-move-from-cravath-to-paul-weiss/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/anatomy-of-a-deal-the-backstory-behind-scott-barshays-move-from-cravath-to-paul-weiss/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Scott Barshay (courtesy of Paul, Weiss; © Matt Greenslade)

The largest story in the law firm world this week is top M&A lawyer [Scott Barshay’s](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/scott-barshay/) [surprise defection](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/a-deeper-dive-into-scott-barshays-move-from-cravath-to-paul-weiss/) from [Cravath](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/cravath/) to [Paul, Weiss](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/paul-weiss-rifkind-wharton-garrison-llp/). Since the news emerged, we’ve heard different opinions about what he’s like to work for — but there’s no disagreement about his status as a leading corporate lawyer and the significance of his move.

There has been a fair amount of curiosity about how the deal for this dealmaker went down. Hence this follow-up story, peeling back the curtain a little on how the move got made.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
According to the [New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/04/business/dealbook/a-cravath-partner-moves-to-paul-weiss.html?ref=dealbook&_r=2), Barshay got to know PW chair Brad Karp and corporate department head Robert Schumer when he worked with Paul, Weiss defending Xerox against activist investor Carl Icahn. But according to [Bloomberg BNA](https://bol.bna.com/meet-the-headhunter-who-placed-scott-barshay-at-paul-weiss/), the official overture that ultimately resulted in Barshay’s hiring came through a longtime legal recruiter, [Mark Rosen](http://www.markbruce.net/bios.htm) of [Mark Bruce International](http://www.markbruce.net/index.htm).

Rosen said that the deal came together fairly quickly as partner moves go, in about two months. As he told Casey Sullivan of [Bloomberg BNA](https://bol.bna.com/meet-the-headhunter-who-placed-scott-barshay-at-paul-weiss/), in February of this year Rosen called Brad Karp and communicated Barshay’s willingness to meet up and talk transition. Subsequent meetings — some of them over meals at Le Bernardin, according to Michael de la Merced of [DealBook](http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/04/business/dealbook/a-cravath-partner-moves-to-paul-weiss.html?ref=dealbook&_r=2) — culminated in Barshay’s lateral move.

Why did Scott Barshay make the move? According to Rosen, Barshay was “frustrated” or “not 100 percent happy” about some aspects of Cravath, and one of them was compensation. As we’ve [previously discussed](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/a-deeper-dive-into-scott-barshays-move-from-cravath-to-paul-weiss/), Barshay stands to make a good bit more money under PW’s modified lockstep system compared to CSM’s pure lockstep system.

Indeed, as Julie Triedman noted in an [Am Law Daily piece](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202754085308/Rainmakers-Defection-Could-Test-Cravath-Lockstep-Model-?cn=20160405&pt=Am%20Law%20Daily%20Breaking%20News&src=EMC-Email&et=editorial&bu=The%20American%20Lawyer&slreturn=20160306170036), the Barshay move raises questions about the viability of a hard-line lockstep model in an increasingly competitive world for talent. I reached out to longtime legal recruiter [Sharon Mahn](http://www.mahnconsultingllc.com/), one of the industry observers contacted by Triedman, and Mahn had this to say of pure lockstep: “Although the lockstep model is not going away anytime soon, it is understandably hard for partners with big books of business to resist market factors that can reward them with higher salaries at competing firms. It is not always just about the money when a partner jumps ship to another platform, but eight-figure compensation is certainly a strong motivation, and that puts the lockstep model under pressure.”

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Of course, Cravath and culturally similar firms like Cleary and Debevoise might turn their noses up at money as a motivator for a move. We summed up that view in a 2012 story, [Biglaw: It’s Not All About the Benjamins](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/09/biglaw-its-not-all-about-the-benjamins/).

In fairness to Paul, Weiss and to Scott Barshay, however, (1) PW is a fairly lockstep firm, with [90 percent of partners getting paid based on seniority](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202754085308/Rainmakers-Defection-Could-Test-Cravath-Lockstep-Model-?cn=20160405&pt=Am%20Law%20Daily%20Breaking%20News&src=EMC-Email&et=editorial&bu=The%20American%20Lawyer&slreturn=20160306170036), and (2) Barshay made his move mainly because of excitement over the PW platform and the chance to grow its practice, as opposed to comp. As Mark Rosen told Bloomberg, Barshay “felt it was a great opportunity. It was the right time, and coming up as the global head of M&A at Paul Weiss was very exciting.”

Lawyers can minimize the importance of compensation and talk about the importance of serving their clients. Legal recruiters can similarly talk about helping candidates advance their careers, but it’s probably fair to say that legal recruiting, as a sales-focused business that’s not a profession in the same way as law, is more (even if not all) about the benjamins.

So how much might Mark Rosen have made from this placement? I posed this question to [Sharon Mahn](http://www.mahnconsultingllc.com/), who as a recruiter has moved prominent partners and practice groups from firm to firm.

“The standard fee is usually 25 percent of the candidate’s first-year base compensation, although it could range to anywhere from 20 to 30 percent of overall compensation, including bonuses,” she said. “If a group moves, it could be a sliding scale of 25 percent for the first partner, 20 percent for the second partner, and so on.”

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Let’s assume, on the conservative side, that Barshay is getting paid a base of $8 million and that Rosen is getting just 20 percent. That’s a cool $1.6 million. On the high end, say 30 percent of $10 million total compensation, that’s $3 million. The actual figure probably lies somewhere in between, perhaps in the $2 million range. But there are some other factors possibly at play here, according to Mahn.

“Mark [mentioned](https://bol.bna.com/meet-the-headhunter-who-placed-scott-barshay-at-paul-weiss/) that he was ‘on retainer’ for a couple of years with Paul Weiss,” Mahn noted. “Under the retainer agreement, Paul, Weiss might have paid him some money up front to conduct their searches, but might have paid less on the back end once a candidate was placed at the firm.”

“Paul Weiss may have also ‘capped’ all candidate placements,” she explained. “That’s a caveat inserted in many law firm fee agreements to ensure that the recruiter fee is not extraordinarily high when it comes to large groups, law firm mergers, or in this case, a candidate that is bringing an astronomical sum of business to the firm with overall compensation to match. The usual cap is $1 million, sometimes $2 million. But it’s also possible Paul, Weiss in this case could have waived the fee cap, as Barshay is a one of the top corporate partners in the industry with an enormous client following.”

The bottom line: it’s hard to say exactly how much Mark Rosen made from this placement, but it’s safe to say that his fateful February phone call culminated in a seven-figure pay day. That might be a lot better than billing thousands of hours over the course of a year to break the million-dollar mark as a typical partner.

But before you run off to become a legal recruiter, you should know that it’s hard work. As described in this prior post, [5 Reasons To Become A Legal Recruiter](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/09/5-reasons-to-become-a-legal-recruiter/), “Recruiting is not the easy money that it might sound like. You have to work hard every day to foster relationships and keep up with hundreds of people all the time. If you don’t like people, you won’t like recruiting. You also could go several months without a single placement….”

If you are entrepreneurial and can stomach that kind of risk, then recruiting might be right for you. But if you are risk-averse — indeed, if you went to law school precisely because of your risk aversion — you might prefer to stay right where you are, ignoring recruiters’ cold calls instead of making them.

[Meet the Headhunter Who Placed Scott Barshay at Paul Weiss](https://bol.bna.com/meet-the-headhunter-who-placed-scott-barshay-at-paul-weiss/) [Big Law Business / Bloomberg BNA]

# The Secret To Lawyer Happiness? Zero Debt!
## Tell that to law schools with their abysmal tuition costs....
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 9, 2021 at 3:15 PMSeptember 9, 2021 at 2:21 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/the-secret-to-lawyer-happiness-zero-debt/&text=The%20Secret%20To%20Lawyer%20Happiness?%20Zero%20Debt!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/the-secret-to-lawyer-happiness-zero-debt/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/the-secret-to-lawyer-happiness-zero-debt/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
My definite observation over the course of my own career is that the happiest lawyers are the debt-free ones.

— Diane Costigan, Director of Coaching and Well-Being at Winston & Strawn, commenting on [wellness issues that heavily indebted lawyers face](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/legal-employers-should-make-financial-wellness-part-employees-well-being-2021-09-09/) during their careers. During Lawyer Well-Being Week this past May, the firm hosted a financial behaviorist for a workshop on how lawyers could manage their finances.

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 04.17.18
## * The Incredible Shrinking Biglaw Partnership: Who'd have thought the idea of making more money by sharing it with fewer people would be so popular? [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1032555/why-biglaw-s-partnerships-are-shrinking)] * Mayer Brown has a new managing partner. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2018/04/16/mayer-brown-appoints-former-london-head-clay-as-managing-partner-405-12779/)] * In the Democratic Republic of Congo, the president just fired 256 judges for, by and large, not having law degrees. That's so weird, over here our judging problem are all the unfit hacks with law degrees. [[Al Jazeera](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/04/dr-congo-president-sacks-256-judges-law-degrees-180417062748072.html)] * How do you expeditiously sort through millions of pages of documents in a wide-ranging criminal investigation? That's a question Robert Mueller's team has, and one that legal technology can actually answer. [[Legaltech News](https://www.law.com/2018/04/16/questions-over-collection-and-review-pile-up-in-mueller-investigation1/)] * Merely threatening frivolous defamation claims can be big business. Charles Harder made $93,000 off Trump's fear of Fire and Fury. [[CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/16/trump-campaign-paid-lawyer-to-warn-steve-bannon-michael-wolff-over-fire-and-fury.html)] * Neil Gorsuch seems to understand diversity in practice better than his colleagues. [[Slate](https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/04/the-supreme-court-is-terrible-at-hiring-diverse-law-clerks-but-neil-gorsuch-is-surprisingly-good-at-it.html)] * Sheppard Mullin sets up a new lateral-fueled Dallas office. [[Texas Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2018/04/16/sheppard-mullin-launches-dallas-office-with-10-lateral-partners/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 17, 2018 at 8:19 AM
1

* The Incredible Shrinking Biglaw Partnership: Who’d have thought the idea of making more money by sharing it with fewer people would be so popular? [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1032555/why-biglaw-s-partnerships-are-shrinking)]

# No One’s Where They Expected To Be
## The legal industry is changing in unexpected ways this year.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 2, 2021 at 10:45 AMJune 7, 2021 at 9:31 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/no-ones-where-they-expected-to-be/&text=No%20One’s%20Where%20They%20Expected%20To%20Be)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/no-ones-where-they-expected-to-be/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/no-ones-where-they-expected-to-be/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Dia Dipasupil/Getty Images)

More law firms announce that they aren’t expecting associates to be back full-time in the office in the fall. More law schools announce that they aren’t expecting enrolled law students to be in class at all. And more Kardashians announce that they aren’t lawyers yet.

# Morning Docket: 04.16.19
## * Varsity Blues students receive target letters, which are basically acceptance letters to the criminal justice system. [[NY Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/15/us/lori-loughlin-mossimo-not-guilty.html)] * Greg Craig looking at an August trial date. That may sound soon, but this matter is all about the rushin'. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2019/04/15/august-trial-date-eyed-in-case-against-greg-craig-ex-skadden-partner/)] * The Department of the Interior has opened an ethics investigation into its new head. He was confirmed a mere four days ago. [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/interior-department-opens-ethics-inquiry-into-new-leader/)] * Circuit splits are on the rise and many are blaming the Supreme Court for not taking up the important cases for judicial efficiency. Who'd have thought morphing the body into an ideology factory would have a downside? [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1149987/high-court-s-light-docket-keeps-circuits-split-legal-pros-say)] * Google has a database of every physical location you've visited that they willingly share with law enforcement. Enjoy! [[How To Geek](https://www.howtogeek.com/411387/how-to-stop-googles-sensorvault-from-sharing-your-location-with-law-enforcement/)] * Legal operations are entering the law school curriculum in the event your legal dream is to be an efficiency expert for Biglaw. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/04/12/legal-operations-is-making-its-way-into-the-law-school-curriculum-405-35149/)] * The sitting president compared interest in his finances as an elected official to FBI harassment of civil rights leaders. This is a thing that really happened. [[Daily Beast](https://www.thedailybeast.com/trump-taxes-presidents-lawyer-invokes-black-civil-rights-leaders-to-keep-tax-returns-secret)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)

[In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/in-house-counsel/)
# In-House Q&A: Hazelden Betty Ford Foundation's Jennifer Lohse
## The foundation's GC weighs in on the in-house career path and the importance of making a difference.
By Jonathan Wolf  
onJuly 13, 2021 at 11:49 AMJuly 13, 2021 at 1:57 PM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/in-house-qa-hazelden-betty-ford-foundations-jennifer-lohse/&text=In-House%20Q&A:%20Hazelden%20Betty%20Ford%20Foundation’s%20Jennifer%20Lohse)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/in-house-qa-hazelden-betty-ford-foundations-jennifer-lohse/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/in-house-qa-hazelden-betty-ford-foundations-jennifer-lohse/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Jennifer Lohse is general counsel at the Hazelden Betty Ford Foundation.

She also had the unique experience of starting in an in-house counsel role right out of law school, in order to build the legal department at a major health company from the ground up.

Lohse has a lot to share about the in-house experience, and some great advice for anyone searching for the ideal position.

(This interview has been edited for length and clarity.)

Why don’t we start with a little bit about your background?

I went to St. Ben’s for undergrad and the University of St. Thomas for law school, graduated in 2005. But before I graduated, I worked for a company called Center for Diagnostic Imaging. I worked as their legislative/law intern.

The strange thing is, there wasn’t another lawyer there, but I worked in their government affairs space helping out with legislative sessions in different states, and doing some federal work. I’ve always been really interested in healthcare.

What was the genesis of that? Was there a particular event that precipitated that interest, or was it just always something you found fascinating?

Well, I had wanted to go to medical school. Then family events and life events led me to law school, which was what everyone was pushing me towards anyway.

I had done some internships, been a PCA at a group home, that sort of thing, all anticipating going to med school. But all my supervisors said I should really think about law school.

I didn’t know lawyers; I didn’t know anything about practicing law. I had experience with doctors, but I had no experience with lawyers. I was like, why is everybody pushing me this way?

Sure.

I sort of took the law school entrance exam on a whim, and actually more or less to get some people off my back about exploring that as an option. I ended up doing relatively well, well enough to apply for and get into a couple law schools. I ended up going to St. Thomas. It was probably a good move. We’re coming up on, oh, what is it, about 16 years later here?

Sometimes it’s best not to think about.

Ha, yeah. So, I started working at CDI while I was in law school. It was either my 1L year summer or just shortly after summer had ended.

I started going to committee hearings, writing different memos on pending legislation, that sort of thing. When I graduated, and passed the bar, they offered me an attorney position at CDI.

I probably should have said “no” as a brand-new baby lawyer. But I didn’t. I said “yes,” and became their first in-house lawyer. I continued to work in the government relations space, but expanded beyond that to eventually lead the legal department as we grew.

Beginning during the Recession we engaged in many years of significant acquisitions, eventually leading us to become a much larger company than when I had started. I developed the legal and compliance department along the way.

Eventually, I took over the risk management at the company as well. I got a lot of trial-by-fire experience.

It really sounds like it. That’s a very unique experience. Most in-house people come from a Biglaw firm and go in-house, you were kind of the opposite. Do you have an opinion on the biggest challenge you faced coming into an in-house position right out of law school like that?

The biggest challenge was that I didn’t have the practical knowledge that I needed. I spent quite a few years of my life completely scared out of my mind that I was going to make a huge mistake.

But I think the saving grace for me was that I had cultivated relationships with the right people, who let me vent to them, and express my concerns and my fears in a very nonjudgmental environment. They gave me the confidence to put one foot in front of the other and keep on going.

I found out I naturally like to lead. I like to lead on projects. I loved to put together the partnerships that we did at CDI.

The area of healthcare is very novel, and it’s very gray. It changes all the time. I was finding myself feeling like I needed better experience being a lawyer before putting these things together.

Then we had the new rules that came down to govern healthcare companies about that same time. I was learning this in real time with the vets. Then all of a sudden there are all these new healthcare regulations that were coming at us, and I was in the same boat that they all were in. We were figuring it out together.

As new rulings came down, we were rejiggering on partnerships and putting things together in different ways.

I bet you probably felt like you were at more of a disadvantage with the veterans than you actually were with all that new stuff coming down the pipeline. People can certainly pretend they know more than anyone else, but when it just came out, everyone knows about the same amount. At any rate, what was your favorite thing about having greater control over your department given that you were building it from the ground up?

I liked being able to keep some of the fun work in-house as my department grew. As we grew the department, another thing I really liked was working with other lawyers and helping them achieve what they wanted to do.

One of them started as a paralegal, and she earned her law degree, so we hired her as a lawyer. I loved that relationship of helping her develop, and helping her find what she really liked about her day-to-day work.

I noticed pretty early on that the legal department needed a strategic plan, along with the company’s strategic plan. I really enjoyed that planning aspect as well.

Now I understand you’re at a fairly well-known nonprofit. Why did you choose to go to Hazelden?

Yes, I’m general counsel at the Hazelden Betty Ford Foundation. I consternated about whether this was going backwards in my career after I had built up a department at a larger company.

Definitely I had started to think I wanted to work in a nonprofit setting though. I wasn’t actively looking when the opportunity at Hazelden came up, but this opportunity presented itself, and I thought, well, I might as well look into it and see what it’s about. It just seemed to really fit.

I’m a mom of two kids, and when I spend my time away from them, I want it to look a certain way. I certainly feel like I’m making a difference even from the legal department at Hazelden, which is absolutely saving people’s lives every day as an organization.

Feeling like you’re making a difference I think becomes more and more important the further along you get in the career. As opposed to just making money early on, or just making money for someone, anyway. Well, anything else you would like to add, or any parting advice you have to people coming up?

If I could leave them with anything, it would be to break the mold. There is no one pathway to get to your ideal position. It doesn’t have to be a big company. It doesn’t have to be the big firm to in-house pipeline.

Be open to opportunities that come up, and that fit your needs, your development needs, your lifestyle needs, that sort of thing. Because that is going to ultimately be the best test of whether that position is right for you.

Jonathan Wolf is a civil litigator and author of [Your Debt-Free JD](https://amzn.to/38fQXp4) (affiliate link). He has taught legal writing, written for a wide variety of publications, and made it both his business and his pleasure to be financially and scientifically literate. Any views he expresses are probably pure gold, but are nonetheless solely his own and should not be attributed to any organization with which he is affiliated. He wouldn’t want to share the credit anyway. He can be reached at [jon_wolf@hotmail.com](mailto:jon_wolf@hotmail.com).

# After 70 Years At Weil, This Senior Partner Is Most Proud Of Helping RBG Become An Appellate Judge
## An amazing accomplishment indeed.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 24, 2021 at 3:15 PMSeptember 24, 2021 at 6:42 PM
50
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/after-70-years-at-weil-this-senior-partner-is-most-proud-of-helping-rbg-become-an-appellate-judge/&text=After%2070%20Years%20At%20Weil,%20This%20Senior%20Partner%20Is%20Most%20Proud%20Of%20Helping%20RBG%20Become%20An%20Appellate%20Judge)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/after-70-years-at-weil-this-senior-partner-is-most-proud-of-helping-rbg-become-an-appellate-judge/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/after-70-years-at-weil-this-senior-partner-is-most-proud-of-helping-rbg-become-an-appellate-judge/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Public domain image via National Archives and Records Administration)

I am particularly proud that many firm partners acted to support the career of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the wife of the late Marty Ginsburg, former well-known head of Weil’s premier tax department.

I knew through my practice several Senate Republicans, including Orrin Hatch of Utah, chair of the judiciary committee, and arranged for the senator to have lunch with myself and Ruth Bader Ginsburg before the judiciary committee advanced her nomination to become a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in 1980. I like to think I played a small part in helping the Ginsburgs navigate the arduous process of getting to the nation’s highest court. I am most proud of the fact that the firm and my partners are proud too.

— [Ira Millstein](https://www.weil.com/people/ira-millstein), a senior partner who just celebrated his 70th year at Weil Gotshal, reflecting on an accomplishment that he’s “particularly proud of,” in a recent interview with [Law.com](https://www.law.com/2021/09/23/in-70-years-at-weil-antitrust-partner-millstein-has-seen-legal-business-transform/). “I feel lucky enough to live at least to 95 years old and to look back at so many of the clients I work with and believe I helped in their own careers,” he said.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Courts](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/courts/), [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/), [Ruth Bader Ginsburg](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ruth-bader-ginsburg/), [Supreme Court](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/supreme-court/), [Weil Gotshal](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/weil-gotshal-manges-llp/)

[Associate Salaries](https://abovethelaw.com/associate-salaries/), [Boutique Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/boutique-law-firms/), [Money](https://abovethelaw.com/money/)
# Prestigious Litigation Boutique Announces Nationwide Salary Raises To $190K!!!
## These trial attorneys will now be earning top dollar. Congratulations!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 10, 2016 at 2:11 PMJune 25, 2016 at 4:00 PM
13
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/prestigious-litigation-boutique-announces-nationwide-salary-raises-to-190k/&text=Prestigious%20Litigation%20Boutique%20Announces%20Nationwide%20Salary%20Raises%20To%20$190K!!!)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/prestigious-litigation-boutique-announces-nationwide-salary-raises-to-190k/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/prestigious-litigation-boutique-announces-nationwide-salary-raises-to-190k/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Earlier today, we reported that [Desmarais had announced major salary moves](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/elite-ip-litigation-boutique-shatters-the-market-leaves-cravath-raises-in-the-dust/) in response to Cravath’s new salary scale. The firm was the second member of the $160K-Plus Club to publicly announce associate raises, preceded by [McKool Smith’s announcement](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/a-member-of-the-160k-plus-club-raises-associate-salaries-nationwide/) yesterday. Thus afternoon, yet another member of that elite club has stepped up to the plate to announce changes to their already generous salary offerings.

Susman Godfrey, a firm known for recruiting associates exclusively from the ranks of former federal law clerks, including Supreme Court clerks, will raise salaries for first-year associates to $190,000, effective July 1. The firm’s salary scale tops out at $300K for sixth-year associates, which is $20K above the Cravath salary scale.

UPDATE (6/25/2016, 4:00 p.m.): Actually, Susman should be seen as matching rather than beating the [Cravath scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/?rf=1). Because all Susman associates come to the firm with at least one year of clerkship experience, what Susman calls “first-year” associates in its press release are really “second-year” associates everywhere else, and Susman’s “sixth-year” associates are the equivalent of “seventh-year” associates at Cravath.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
In a press release announcing the good news, managing partner [Stephen Susman](http://www.susmangodfrey.com/attorneys/stephen-d-susman/) said:

“We pay our associates top salaries and bonuses because we expect — and receive — the best from them,” said Stephen D. Susman, Susman Godfrey Managing Partner. “We are incredibly selective when hiring associates, with a talent pool hailing from the nation’s top law schools. In addition, we only hire law students who’ve clerked for a judge in the federal court system, as it’s the best training for a young trial attorney.”

Susman continued: “We’ve found that giving associates substantive responsibility, making them privy to the firm’s financials, and letting them vote — on an equal standing with partners — on virtually all firm decisions, have enabled us to recruit and retain better lawyers.”

Congratulations to all associates at Susman & Godfrey! The firm typically pays out beaucoup year-end bonus bucks that far exceed industry standards, so we’re sure your student loans will be paid off in no time!

Remember, we are covering this trend extensively, so please drop us a line — text (646-820-8477) or [email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”) — when you know of another firm making a compensation move. Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file. All sources are kept strictly confidential.

# Winning Deals, Cases, And Clients With Legal Data
## Join us on [December 10th](https://info.breakingmedia.com/winning-deals-cases-and-clients-with-legal-data) to skillfully integrate data analytics into your day-to-day, ultimately increasing your negotiation, litigation, and business development prowess.
By [Above The Law and Gavelytics](https://info.breakingmedia.com/winning-deals-cases-and-clients-with-legal-data)  
onNovember 2, 2020 at 12:46 PMNovember 2, 2020 at 11:59 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/winning-deals-cases-and-clients-with-legal-data/&text=Winning%20Deals,%20Cases,%20And%20Clients%20With%20Legal%20Data)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/winning-deals-cases-and-clients-with-legal-data/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/winning-deals-cases-and-clients-with-legal-data/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Powerful legal data products hold the promise of making your litigation arguments truly hit home,
or of helping you skillfully negotiate transactions, or even of growing your firm’s business pipeline.

But how can you ensure you’re accurately discerning the stories these enormous bodies of data can tell? And what pitfalls should you be on the
lookout for in leveraging data to bolster your practice?

Join us on December 10th at 1 p.m. ET / 10 a.m. PT to learn how — and how not — to skillfully integrate data analytics into your day-to-day, ultimately increasing your negotiation, litigation, and business development prowess.

The discussion will feature:

- An overview of how law firms of all sizes can use legal data to improve numerous aspects of their operations.
- Pitfalls to look for when analyzing data for use in a variety of contexts.
- An in-depth look at data-driven tools to refine your practice in state courts.
Presenters:
Rick Merrill, Founder and CEO, Gavelytics
Justin Brownstone, VP of Sales and Litigation Counsel, Gavelytics
John DiGilio, Firmwide Director of Library Services, Sidley Austin LLP
Jason Nittel, Director, Litigation Technology & Support, Allen Matkins

Moderator:
Bob Ambrogi – Founder of LawSites blog, Technology Columnist at Above the Law

By filling out the form, you are opting in to receive communication from Above the Law and its Partners.

# Being Married To A Lawyer Isn't All It's Cracked Up To Be
## This lawyer's spouse said, 'I wouldn’t wish this half-life on anyone.'
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 23, 2021 at 3:42 PMFebruary 24, 2021 at 6:41 AM
166
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/being-married-to-a-lawyer-isnt-all-its-cracked-up-to-be/&text=Being%20Married%20To%20A%20Lawyer%20Isn’t%20All%20It’s%20Cracked%20Up%20To%20Be)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/being-married-to-a-lawyer-isnt-all-its-cracked-up-to-be/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/being-married-to-a-lawyer-isnt-all-its-cracked-up-to-be/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Does it ever get better? [My husband is] a lovely man and he earns a good salary but I’m twenty or so years in and the work never stops. I mean never. Not on holiday. Not during births. Not during house moves. …

I am getting a bit tired of being at the bottom of the priority list which appears to be: work, children (quite rightly), dog, household necessities, life admin, wife. Except by the time he gets time to focus on me he is so tired his eyes literally glaze over when we speak. I try not to take it personally.

— a lawyer’s spouse writing a [rather candid post](https://www.legalcheek.com/2021/02/i-wouldnt-wish-this-half-life-on-anyone-mumsnet-discusses-life-married-to-a-lawyer/) about what seems to be a one-sided marriage on [Mumsnet](https://www.mumsnet.com/Talk/relationships/4163205-Those-of-you-married-to-a-lawyer), a UK parenting forum. While some responded with thoughtful advice, others familiar with this woman’s plight referred to it as “the nature of the beast,” and others still called her husband a “workaholic.”

# New Biglaw Partner Class Is Pretty Encouraging
## Women face hurdles reaching partnership all across Biglaw, but White & Case's new class breaks that trend.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onOctober 12, 2018 at 10:47 AM
17
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/new-biglaw-partner-class-is-pretty-encouraging/&text=New%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Class%20Is%20Pretty%20Encouraging)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/new-biglaw-partner-class-is-pretty-encouraging/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/new-biglaw-partner-class-is-pretty-encouraging/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The legal profession is notoriously stingy when it comes to advancing women. Earlier this week, we got a look at exactly how stingy when the National Association of Women Lawyers [released a new study](https://www.nawl.org/p/cm/ld/fid=1163), summarized in [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/10/new-report-finds-female-path-to-law-firm-partnership-a-sluggish-crawl/), finding that among the Am Law 200, women comprise a mere 20 percent of the equity partner population despite entering the profession as roughly 47 percent of associates.

Which is what makes today’s partner promotion announcement from White & Case so encouraging. Flipping through the bios of the 41 attorneys promoted to partnership this year, roughly 46 percent of whom are women, placing the firm… right in line with the profession’s demographics. That’s not going to solve decades of underrepresentation across the entire Biglaw landscape, but if every firm could follow White & Case’s lead, it would go a long way toward setting things right.

White & Case Chairman Hugh Verrier notes that:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
This year’s class is the largest in our history, which illustrates the level of talent we have cultivated within the Firm. As we grow the White & Case partnership through both internal promotions and lateral hires, we are poised to deliver on our 2020 Strategy.

The 2020 strategy involves growing numbers in the U.S. and London, and perusing the new class it appears as though around 61 percent of the new partners come from those locations so that tracks.

Congratulations to all the new partners at White & Case. You can check out the complete list on the next page.

[New Report Finds Female Path to Law Firm Partnership a Sluggish Crawl](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/10/new-report-finds-female-path-to-law-firm-partnership-a-sluggish-crawl/) [American Lawyer]
[2018 National Association of Women Lawyers Survey on Retention and Promotion of Women in Law Firms](https://www.nawl.org/p/cm/ld/fid=1163) [NAWL]

# Lawyer Writes Epic Departure Memo... Actually Seems Happy?
## Woah, this lawyer actually seems sad to leave his job.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 4, 2016 at 12:01 PM
41
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/lawyer-writes-epic-departure-memo-actually-seems-happy/&text=Lawyer%20Writes%20Epic%20Departure%20Memo…%20Actually%20Seems%20Happy?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/lawyer-writes-epic-departure-memo-actually-seems-happy/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/lawyer-writes-epic-departure-memo-actually-seems-happy/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Like a unicorn in the wild, we have here something I never thought I’d see while working for Above the Law: a lawyer who is happy with his job. Okay, sure, this lawyer is on his way out of the firm he spent over a decade slaving away at, but he seems genuinely sad to go. Perhaps it is all the adrenaline left over from handing in his notice, but on this cold Friday morning I choose to see it as a sign. A sign that beyond all the drudgery and long hours, some people really enjoy their life in a law firm. Sure, I’ve only read about those people online, and never met one in person, but this departure memo gives me hope that it is real.

We received the email below from an attorney heading out of the door. Littered with graphics and memes, it shows law firms don’t have to be the place where humor goes to die. So while you’re busy fantasizing about your exit from your firm (flame on!), this is a nice reminder that is it possible to leave with grace and the last laugh. Enjoy!

To:
Cc:

When I received an offer 11 years ago to be a summer clerk at Bracewell (& Patterson), I had no idea it would become such a large part of my life…

 

…which has made today, my last at the firm, bittersweet.

Although I will miss working with each of you, I am looking forward to the challenge of starting a new phase of my career as a partner at Wick Phillips. 

But before I go, I want to take a moment to thank you…


First, to Special Services for your tireless behind-the-scenes support. Enormous print jobs, late-day rush requests, and my annual Christmas avalanche of Amazon packages – nothing seems to faze you.


To all the admins, assistants, paralegals, and staff: thank you for making us look like competent lawyers…even when we don’t make it easy for you. We would not be nearly as successful without your support.

And finally, to my fellow attorneys, thank you for educating me through your example that being a good person is essential to being a great lawyer.  Bracewell has been a collaborative (and fun) place to learn how to practice law.

 

I wish all of you the absolute best. My contact information is included in the attached vCard.  Save it. Use it. Stay in touch. 

(tl;dr – Last day, thanks)

# As Law Firms Self-Reflect, State Bar Exams Double Down
## The George Floyd killing is inspiring law firms to reconsider their policies, while bar exams ask applicants to sign liability waivers.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 9, 2020 at 5:17 PMJune 9, 2020 at 2:50 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/as-law-firms-self-reflect-state-bar-exams-double-down/&text=As%20Law%20Firms%20Self-Reflect,%20State%20Bar%20Exams%20Double%20Down)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/as-law-firms-self-reflect-state-bar-exams-double-down/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/as-law-firms-self-reflect-state-bar-exams-double-down/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As law firms struggle to demonstrate to clients and their own attorneys that they take societal ills seriously, Kathryn’s starting to notice some patterns in the statements getting released. Meanwhile, Joe is covering the state bar exams, where many are continuing to insist on shoving hundreds of people into small rooms in July and making applicants sign away their rights for the privilege of exposing themselves to disease.

Thanks to Logikcull for sponsoring.

And be sure to check out our Special Reports podcast, the [ATL COVID Cast](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/covid-cast-podcast/), discussing the unexpected ways that the outbreak will change the legal landscape.
