# Biglaw Firm Starts The Weekend Off On The Right Foot By Announcing Raises, Bonuses
## It's Friday, Friday, associates getting paid on Friday!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 15, 2023 at 10:50 AMDecember 15, 2023 at 11:04 AM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/kramer-levin-compensation-2023/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Starts%20The%20Weekend%20Off%20On%20The%20Right%20Foot%20By%20Announcing%20Raises,%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/kramer-levin-compensation-2023/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/kramer-levin-compensation-2023/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
One by one, Biglaw bonuses and raises continue to be announced. Wondering when your firm may make its move? Some large law firms are still deciding if they can “afford” to raise salaries (hint: they very likely can), but we certainly hope your big payday will be coming soon.

In the meantime, we’ve now confirmed that Kramer — a firm that brought in $421,443,000 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 102 in the most recent Am Law 100 — has chosen to use the Cravath scale for its compensation increases, meaning these are the salaries associates at the firm will see, effective January 1, 2024:

- Class of 2023 – $225,000
- Class of 2022 – $235,000
- Class of 2021 – $260,000
- Class of 2020 – $310,000
- Class of 2019 – $365,000
- Class of 2018 – $390,000
- Class of 2017 – $420,000
- Class of 2016+ – $435,000
Kramer Levin is also matching the Cravath bonus scale, and this is what year-end bonuses will look like at the firm, to be paid on February 15, 2024:

- Class of 2022 – $20,000
- Class of 2021 – $30,000
- Class of 2020 – $57,500
- Class of 2019 – $75,000
- Class of 2018 – $90,000
- Class of 2017 – $105,000
- Class of 2016+ – $115,000
Members of the Class of 2023 will receive an annualized bonus of $15,000, prorated to October 2, 2023.

Congratulations to everyone at Kramer Levin!

(Flip to the next page to read the full memo from the firm.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of compensation updates, so when your firm announces or matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus/Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus/Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Tipsters Help ATL Be A Positive Force In The Legal Industry
## Above the Law and our tipsters: partners in building a better legal world.
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onMarch 17, 2023 at 3:15 PMMarch 17, 2023 at 1:51 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/tipsters-help-atl-be-a-positive-force-in-the-legal-industry/&text=Tipsters%20Help%20ATL%20Be%20A%20Positive%20Force%20In%20The%20Legal%20Industry)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/tipsters-help-atl-be-a-positive-force-in-the-legal-industry/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/03/tipsters-help-atl-be-a-positive-force-in-the-legal-industry/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A few weeks ago, I was listening to one of my favorite podcasts, the “Thinking Like a Lawyer” podcast produced by Above the Law. Everyone should listen to the podcast, not just because the banter between the hosts is genuinely entertaining but because the podcast is a good way to be apprised of legal news stories you might have missed during the preceding week.

During the podcast, the hosts discussed a wild legal news story I could not believe I missed and conveyed that it was thanks to the help of Above the Law tipsters that the story got attention from legal news outlets. This made me think how Above the Law can be a positive force within the legal industry with the help of solid tipsters, since tipsters can help call out bad behavior and this incentivizes the powers that be to behave themselves better.

I have been reading Above the Law for nearly a decade and a half, and the news outlet has broken a number of stories within the legal profession during that time. Even when I was in law school, there was a sense that people should not go too crazy at school or while they worked as summer associates since they might end up on Above the Law. One year, a group of law students produced a funny law review video on this topic, but for the life of me, I can’t find it now! I am not sure that any of my classmates changed their behaviors for fear of being on Above the Law, but it was definitely something that people discussed at school.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
When I started working as an associate in Biglaw, people also discussed how the firm and partners might be more likely to follow good practices for fear of being featured on Above the Law. The firm at which I worked had made the pages of Above the Law for all kinds of conduct that possibly crossed lines, and I have to believe that partners were thinking about the bad publicity of an Above the Law story when they made certain decisions.

Over the years, tipsters have informed Above the Law about all kinds of bad conduct at law firms and other facets of the legal industry that might go under the radar for other news sources. For instance, many writers at Above the Law have publicized stealth layoffs at law firms, a situation in which a law firm does not expressly tell associates they are fired but convinces them they should find work elsewhere. Moreover, many articles have discussed how law firms might blame layoffs on performance issues rather than economic reasons to save face even if this makes it harder for a lawyer to find work. I have to believe that these stories, and the publicity that surrounds them, might move the needle for law firm partners and convince them that they should adopt better practices not only to treat associates better but to avoid negative publicity.

Above the Law has an amazing tipster network. Before the pandemic, I went to a bunch of Above the Law events in New York City and met tons of people who discussed how they had provided tips to Above the Law. These folks were not just lawyers. People tend to forget that the legal industry contains numerous kinds of professionals — law firm administrators, secretaries, paralegals, law librarians, and others — who are just as likely to be consumers of news about the legal industry and dish information about lawyers and law firms that might make the pages of Above the Law.

Above the Law frequently solicits tips, but I just wanted to put in my own two cents and relate that tips not only help Above the Law provide solid content to readers but also has a positive impact on the legal industry. Through each period of turmoil within the legal industry over the past decade and a half or so, Above the Law has been there, writing articles based on tips that have called people out for policies and practices that are unfair or undignified. Lawyers and law firms might hold themselves to a higher standard when interacting with employees and running their shops so that they do not end up on the pages of Above the Law.

However, Above the Law is only effective as a check on the powers that be within the legal industry if it has solid tipsters to furnish information. As a result, people should be encouraged to provide tips to Above the Law not only because it may lead to solid content for the website but since this can also impose checks on managers within the legal profession.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. # Am Law 100 Firm Lassos A Cravath Match For Associates
## Yeehaw, associates! More money!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 3, 2022 at 12:02 PMMarch 3, 2022 at 12:13 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/vinson-reraise-2022/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Firm%20Lassos%20A%20Cravath%20Match%20For%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/vinson-reraise-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/03/vinson-reraise-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
One by one, Biglaw firms are doing the inevitable during the 2022 associate salary wars: matching Cravath’s generous new compensation grid.

The latest firm to do so is one that already raised salaries just last week. Texas-based Vinson & Elkins — a firm that brought in $782,352,000 gross revenue in 2020, making it No. 59 in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking — [adopted the Davis Polk salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/vinson-raise-2022/) on February 24, and here they are again with a Cravath match. This is what the new salary scale looks like at the firm:


The firm’s salary increases apply to their U.S. and London offices. They’re retroactive to January 1, and associates will see their new compensation in their March 15 paychecks. Congratulations, again!

(Flip to the next page to read the full memo from Vinson & Elkins.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# More Biglaw Firms Are Considering Deferring First-Year Associates
## Uh-oh. Which firm will be the next to announce?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 22, 2023 at 2:16 PM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/more-biglaw-firms-are-considering-deferring-first-year-associates/&text=More%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Are%20Considering%20Deferring%20First-Year%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/more-biglaw-firms-are-considering-deferring-first-year-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/more-biglaw-firms-are-considering-deferring-first-year-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

Those firms thinking along those lines don’t want to be outliers and are hoping to see others thinking similarly.

— [Kent Zimmermann](https://www.consultzg.com/people/kent-zimmermann/), a law firm management consultant with the Zeughauser Group, in comments given to the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/05/22/more-first-year-deferrals-likely-as-firms-grapple-with-dormant-corporate-practices-large-incoming-class-sizes/) on the possibility of more deferrals for first-year associates. Zimmermann said that some firms are working on plans to push their start dates back to January, but no one wants to be the first to announce. [Gunderson Dettmer](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/biglaw-firm-lays-off-10-of-its-workforce-may-defer-incoming-associates/) and [Cooley](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/after-layoffs-last-year-cooley-delays-start-date-for-first-year-associates/) previously announced plans to defer their first-years.

# Some Associates At This Firm Will Get An Extra $40,000 On Top Of The Standard Bonus Scale
## Special bonuses on top of year end bonuses? Yes please!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 11, 2019 at 9:57 AMDecember 11, 2019 at 10:05 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/cahill-bonus-2019/&text=Some%20Associates%20At%20This%20Firm%20Will%20Get%20An%20Extra%20$40,000%20On%20Top%20Of%20The%20Standard%20Bonus%20Scale)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/cahill-bonus-2019/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/cahill-bonus-2019/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
At this point in the bonus cycle, Biglaw observers are well aware of what the elite firm are paying to the associates for their year end bonuses. The scale was set by Milbank over a month ago, and quickly confirmed by Cravath and now that’s what most big firms will be giving their associates. But it is always nice when, in addition to just making the match, firms give a little something extra to the hardest working associates.

That’s just what happened at Cahill Gordon & Reindel. As part of their bonus announcement they indicated that they pay “special bonuses” ranging from $5,000 to $40,000 for “outstanding individual effort.” Nice!

For those that need the reminder, the industry-wide bonus scale that Cahill is matching is as follows:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Class of 2019 – $15,000 (pro-rated)
Class of 2018 – $15,000
Class of 2017 – $25,000
Class of 2016 – $50,000
Class of 2015 – $65,000
Class of 2014 – $80,000
Class of 2013 – $90,000
Class of 2012 – $100,000
Class of 2011 – $100,000

[Read the full memo on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/cahill-bonus-2019/2/)

Remember — we can’t do this without you, dear readers! We depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for all salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

# Has The Legal Profession Had A Negative Effect On Your Mental Health?
## This is incredibly problematic.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 20, 2020 at 1:13 PMFebruary 20, 2020 at 12:38 PM
106
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/has-the-legal-profession-had-a-negative-effect-on-your-mental-health/&text=Has%20The%20Legal%20Profession%20Had%20A%20Negative%20Effect%20On%20Your%20Mental%20Health?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/has-the-legal-profession-had-a-negative-effect-on-your-mental-health/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/has-the-legal-profession-had-a-negative-effect-on-your-mental-health/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I think that’s a very significant finding and points to the fact that we’re falling short of what we could be offering people.At a high level, that is something that is going to repel people from the legal profession.

— [Patrick Krill](https://www.prkrill.com/about), an attorney who is a certified alcohol and drug counselor and works as a consultant to numerous law firms on mental health and substance abuse issues, [commenting](https://www.law.com/2020/02/19/lawyers-reveal-true-depth-of-the-mental-health-struggles/) on the fact that when asked, “Do you think the profession has had a negative effect on your mental health over time?” 74 pecent of the more than 3,800 respondents to [ALM’s Mental Health and Substance Abuse Survey](https://www.law.com/2020/02/19/lawyers-reveal-true-depth-of-the-mental-health-struggles/) said yes.

Here some additional findings from the ALM Survey, some of which may be shocking to you:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
- 56 percent of respondents said mental health problems and substance abuse are worse in the legal industry than in other industries;
- 41 percent of respondents said mental health problems and substance abuse are at a crisis level in the legal industry;
- 17.9 percent of respondents said they have contemplated suicide during their professional legal career;
- 31.2 percent of respondents said they are depressed;
- 64 percent of respondents said they have anxiety;
- 10.1 percent of respondents said they have an alcohol problem; and
- 2.8 percent of respondents said they have a drug problem.
[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).

# In-House Leaders Say Lawyers At These Biglaw Firms Are Client Service 'All-Stars'
## Which firms -- and which lawyers -- came out on top?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 13, 2023 at 2:05 PMJune 13, 2023 at 2:15 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/in-house-leaders-say-lawyers-at-these-biglaw-firms-are-client-service-all-stars/&text=In-House%20Leaders%20Say%20Lawyers%20At%20These%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Are%20Client%20Service%20‘All-Stars’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/in-house-leaders-say-lawyers-at-these-biglaw-firms-are-client-service-all-stars/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/in-house-leaders-say-lawyers-at-these-biglaw-firms-are-client-service-all-stars/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Which Biglaw attorneys are most beloved by general counsel for their superior client service? Thanks to a brand new ranking, we’re about to find out.

The BTI Consulting Group set out to find which lawyers handled in-house client service with ease, adding them to their annual list of “all-stars.” To compile the ranking, between January 2022 and March 2023, BTI spoke with more than 350 in-house decision-makers at large organizations with over $700 million in annual revenue.

[Law360](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1687928?nl_pk=e87be47f-5f1d-47f6-9e89-095ce13995e4) has some coverage on BTI’s annual ranking, with additional details here:

BTI’s president, Michael Rynowecer, told Law360 that many of the companies that nominated attorneys for the report expressed an appreciation for lawyers who can anticipate what their clients need and provide it quickly and efficiently.

“Clients are beyond to their eyeballs in work,” Rynowecer said. “So they’ve come to really value the attorneys who really, at an operating level, know what they need and just offer up those resources.”

Almost 300 attorneys were named to this year’s list, but which firms do they hail from? According to [Law360](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1687928?nl_pk=e87be47f-5f1d-47f6-9e89-095ce13995e4), these are the firms where at least five lawyers were named by in-house client:

- Jones Day: 13
- Gibson Dunn: 11
- Carlton Fields: 6
- Jackson Lewis: 6
- Kirkland & Ellis: 6
- Ogletree Deakins: 6
- Arnold & Porter: 5
- BakerHostetler: 5
- Barnes & Thornburg: 5
- Greenberg Traurig: 5
- Hogan Lovells: 5
- Littler: 5
- Morgan Lewis: 5
With 293 lawyers named to the all-star list, just four were mentioned by more than one client. Which lawyers received the highest honors? As noted by [Law360](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1687928?nl_pk=e87be47f-5f1d-47f6-9e89-095ce13995e4), those lawyers are: [Stephanie L. Adler-Paindiris](https://www.jacksonlewis.com/people/stephanie-l-adler-paindiris) of Jackson Lewis; [Sandra C. Goldstein](https://www.kirkland.com/lawyers/g/goldstein-sandra-c-pc) of Kirkland & Ellis; [Jeff E. Scott](https://www.gtlaw.com/en/professionals/s/scott-jeff-e) of Greenberg Traurig; and [Sara M. Turner](https://www.bakerdonelson.com/Sara-Turner) of Baker Donelson.

Congratulations to Jones Day and Gibson Dunn for leading the pack on being client service all-stars, and an even bigger congratulations to all of the attorneys who were named by more than one client. You’ve proven yourselves to be outstanding when it comes to making corporate clients happy, and that’s worth celebrating.

[GCs Say These Firms Have ‘All-Star’ Attys For Client Services](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1687928?nl_pk=e87be47f-5f1d-47f6-9e89-095ce13995e4) [Law360]

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).
